Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54021-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2021 
 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Promotion of the Northeast Asia Power 
System Interconnection 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 15 November 2021) 
 
Currency unit  –  togrog (MNT) 
MNT1.00  =  $0.0003502357 
$1.00  =  MNT2,855.22 
 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  GHG  –  greenhouse gas 
  GW  –  gigawatt 
  kV  –  kilovolt 
  MW  –  megawatt 
NAPSI  –  Northeast Asia Power System Interconnection 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
ROK  –  Republic of Korea 
SDG  –  Sustainable Development Goal

NOTE  
  
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  Ahmed M. Saeed, Operations 2 
Director General  M. Teresa Kho, East Asia Department (EARD) 
   
Director  Sujata Gupta, Sustainable Infrastructure Division (EASI), EARD 
   
Team leader  Shannon Cowlin, Principal Energy Specialist, EASI, EARDa

a  Outposted to the Mongolia Resident Mission.

territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 23112021180723999973 Generated Date: 23-Nov-2021 18:14:46 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) for the Promotion of the Northeast 
Asia Power System Interconnection (NAPSI) will support necessary analysis for the first step in 
realizing NAPSI. It will build on a previous Asian Development Bank (ADB) TA project that 
developed an overall strategy for NAPSI and demonstrated its value.1 The strategy identified 
several steps to realizing NAPSI, the first of which has three components: (i) development of 
5 gigawatts (GW) of solar and wind generating capacity in the South Gobi region of Mongolia, 
(ii) construction of a transmission interconnection between South Gobi and northern People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), and (iii) construction of an undersea transmission interconnection 
between eastern PRC and the Republic of Korea (ROK). This TA will develop a build-out strategy 
for solar and wind development in the South Gobi region, study alternatives for transmission 
connections to the PRC and/or the ROK, analyze alternative uses for renewable electricity 
generated in the South Gobi region, and support continued multilateral dialogue on Mongolian 
renewable power in the context of NAPSI. The TA is included in the country operations business 
plan for Mongolia, 2021.2 The TA is aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Mongolia 
(2021-2024) strategic priority 2 on climate-resilient infrastructure to drive competitiveness and 
diversification.3   
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Greenhouse gas burden and system constraints. The Northeast Asia region4 accounts 
for 20% of global gross domestic product but is responsible for about 40% of global greenhouse 
gas  (GHG)  emissions.5 Coal,  natural  gas,  and  oil  supplied  70%  of  the  region’s  electricity 
generation in 2018.6 Countries in the region are diversifying their energy mixes to replace fossil 
fuel generation with solar, wind, and hydropower generation, which contributes to improved air 
quality and reduced GHG emissions. The PRC is a global leader in renewable energy, accounting 
for more than one-third of global installed wind and solar electric generating capacity in 2019.7 
However, many other countries in the region face challenges to  expanding their use of renewable 
power because of (i) long distances between high-quality renewable energy resources with large  
economic potential and load centers, (ii) grid systems that are not sufficiently robust and flexible 
to integrate higher levels of variable renewable power, and (iii) land constraints that prevent 
domestic renewable expansion at levels required to reach climate mitigation goals. 
 
3.  Mongolian power system. Coal accounted for 93% of Mongolia’s electricity generation 
in 2018. The Government of Mongolia targets renewable generation reaching 20% of total 
installed capacity by 2023 and 30% by 2030. The government is poised to meet the 2023 target 
with two 50-megawatt (MW) wind farms, two 10 MW solar photovoltaic plants, and more under 
planning and construction. Mongolia imports 20% of its total electricity supply. A 220-kilovolt (kV) 
transmission  line  with  245 MW  capacity  from  Selendeuna  in  Buryatia  in  the  the  Russian 
 
1  ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for the Strategy for Northeast Asia Power System Interconnection. 
Manila.  
2  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia 2020–2021. Manila. The TA first appeared in the business 
opportunities section of ADB’s website on 12 October 2021. 
3 ADB. 2021. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2021–2024— Laying Resilient Foundations for Inclusive and 
Sustainable Growth. Manila. 
4  For this analysis and technical assistance, the Northeast Asia region includes Japan, Mongolia, the People’s Republic 
of China, the Republic of Korea, and the Russian Federation.  
5  ADB. 2020. A Review of the Strategy for the Northeast Asia Power System Interconnection. Manila. 
6 International  Energy  Agency.  Data  and  Statistics.  https://www.iea.org/data-and-statistics/data-
tables?country=WORLD (accessed 11 September 2020). 
7  IRENA. 2020. Renewable Capacity Statistics 2020 International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA). Abu Dhabi.

2 
Federation supplies electricity and provides grid services for Mongolia’s central region’s energy 
system, which covers the major load centers, including Ulaanbaatar. A 220 kV line from the PRC 
supplies power to the Oyu Tolgoi mining operations in southern Mongolia, which iare isolated 
from the rest of the Mongolian grid. A 220 kV line, operating at 110 kV, from Chadan to 
Handagaoly in the Russian Federation feeds the western region’s energy system, supplying up 
to 75% of electricity consumed in that region, although this will decrease once planned wind and 
solar plants in Mongolia are commissioned.8 
 
4.  Mongolia renewable potential and growth in domestic use.  The first NAPSI TA 
(footnote 1) identified tracts of land across Mongolia with high-quality solar and wind energy 
potential, suitable geographic features for development, and proximity to existing infrastructure. 
It estimated Mongolia’s economically viable renewable power capacity potential at 192 GW of 
wind and 1,166 GW of solar photovoltaic. The TA also developed a least-cost expansion scenario 
of Mongolia’s power system to 2036 considering the 2030 target of 30% renewable capacity 
contribution. The model showed that solar and wind installed capacity could each contribute 
1.1 GW to Mongolia’s power system at the end of that period, but with significant curtailment of 
generation from the new capacity because of the lack of flexible generation assets or grid 
management systems. 
 
5.  Potential for export of renewable power. The potential for development of Mongolia’s 
renewable  energy  resources  far  exceeds  projected  domestic  demand  and  could  easily 
accommodate development for export markets. The power trade in the Northeast Asia region is 
currently limited to bilateral trade between the Russian Federation and the PRC, the Russian 
Federation and Mongolia, and the PRC and Mongolia (para. 3). The South Gobi region has 
extensive tracts of land with high-quality renewable resources that are close to the border with 
the PRC, a potential buyer of power generated in that region.  
 
6.  Strategy for NAPSI. The first NAPSI TA analyzed regional power system growth under a 
variety of scenarios to assess the value of an interconnected approach. The TA considered 
markets, technology, resource bases, current power systems, projected demand, and renewable 
energy targets across Northeast Asian countries, and assumptions were agreed through a 
consultative multi-stakeholder approach. The study evaluated scenarios for power system growth 
across the region using an idealized version of the grid where flow was driven by marginal cost 
differences. The analysis showed that an interconnected region would result in net savings of 
about $3 billion per year, compared with a baseline where each country’s power needs are met 
by  domestic  supply.  A  scenario  that  considered  regional  interconnection  plus  100  GW  of 
renewable generation in the South Gobi region of Mongolia resulted in $10 billion in annual 
savings compared with the isolated grid case, plus 210 million tons annually of avoided carbon 
dioxide emissions because of substantial displacement of coal and natural gas generation across 
the region. 
 
7.  First step in building NAPSI. The strategy proposed a stepwise development for NAPSI 
starting with an initial development of renewable energy capacity in Mongolia’s South Gobi region 
and transmission links connecting the South Gobi to PRC and from PRC to ROK. The NAPSI 
study recommended that these be commissioned by 2026 as the first step toward a fully integrated 
regional grid by 2036. Given power shortages in the Seoul region, the link between eastern PRC 
and the ROK is the most pressing. A bilateral agreement to develop this link led to negotiations 
between the Korea Electric Power Corporation and the State Grid Corporation of the PRC on joint 
development of the project. To help the ROK reach climate mitigation goals, the development of 
 
8  UNESCAP. 2018. North-East Asian Regional Power Interconnection and Cooperation Forum 2018: Current Status 
and Progress in Mongolia for Power Interconnection. Ulaanbaatar.

3 
5 GW renewable capacity in the South Gobi region and associated power transmission to the 
ROK would ideally be undertaken at the same time. 
 
8.  Additional analytical needs. The previous TA estimated potential power flows and 
associated regional benefits under idealized scenarios. However, before proceeding to the first 
investment phase, feasibility studies on renewable capacity development and interconnections 
that  consider  actual  conditions  rather  than  idealized  conditions  are  required.  Furthermore, 
potential commercial structuring for transmission and power purchase agreements should be 
evaluated considering regulatory regimes, capacity of state entities, and opportunities for private 
sector  engagement.  The  potential  benefits  for  each  of  the  countries  should  be  estimated, 
disaggregating the regional benefits quantified in the previous TA. This TA will analyze the 
components where Mongolia would play a key role in an integrated NAPSI—the renewable power 
generation development in the South Gobi region, conceptual analysis of interconnection options 
with the PRC, and alternative use cases for renewably generated electricity in the South Gobi 
region. The TA will also support the promotion of Mongolia’s renewable-generated power in a 
regional  power  grid  through  continued  multilateral  dialogue,  including  the  North-East  Asia 
Regional  Power  Interconnection  and  Cooperation  Forum,  organized  by  the  United  Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. Collectively, these efforts will advance 
the concept of a renewably powered NAPSI and increase investment readiness. 
 
9.  Alignment with Strategy 2030. The TA is aligned with several operational priorities of 
Strategy 2030: (i) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental  sustainability;  (ii)  strengthening  governance  and  institutional  capacity;  and 
(iii) fostering regional cooperation and integration.9 The TA also contributes directly to Sustainable 
Development Goal (SDG) 7 on ensuring access to affordable, reliable, and sustainable energy 
for all; SDG 9 on building resilient infrastructure, promoting sustainable industrialization, and 
fostering innovation; and SDG 13 on taking urgent action to combat climate change and its 
impacts. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: energy-efficient and environment-friendly 
technology advanced.10 The TA will have the following outcome: Investment readiness of South 
Gobi renewable energy development for export increased.11 Through the TA, the government will 
promote clean power exports from Mongolia as an essential part of an integrated power system 
spanning Northeast Asian countries. The TA will refine the approach to building solar and wind 
capacity in the South Gobi region and further evaluate its relevance for the NAPSI initiative, 
including the value to neighboring countries. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: South Gobi renewable energy development and export plan developed. 
This output will include three main components: 
(i)  Feasibility study of 5 GW of solar and wind power generating capacity development 
in  Mongolia’s  South Gobi  region.  This  study  will  consider  renewable  resource 
 
9  Asian Development Bank. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia 
and the Pacific. Manila.  
10 Regulatory Indicators for Sustainable Energy. 2015. Mongolia Resolution on Adoption of State Policy of Energy. 
Ulaanbaatar. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
distribution and correlations to maximize smooth power production and existing 
infrastructure; costs for new generation and necessary infrastructure expansion; and 
the  commercial  and  regulatory  environment  for  renewable  power  project 
development. 
(ii)  Study  of  the  transmission  interconnections  from  the  South  Gobi  renewable 
generating base to the PRC. This study will develop a conceptual technical design 
for  a  transmission  interconnection  that  considers  voltage  and  synchronization; 
preferred landing points, including evaluation of landing points in the Inner Mongolia 
Autonomous Region and Shandong Province in the PRC; and the potential for some 
domestic use of the Mongolia-generated renewable power. The study will also 
conduct a financial analysis of the cost of exported power to the ROK relative to the 
cost of electricity in various potential export locations in the PRC. The study will 
analyze the economic value of the preferred interconnection design and potential 
commercial structuring arrangements for developing and operating cross-border 
assets. 
(iii)  Analysis of potential alternatives for renewable power production in the South Gobi 
region, including green hydrogen. This study will consider the potential products and 
markets but also the constraints, such as water availability and proximity of carbon 
sources for synthetic hydrocarbon production. This will be a high-level analysis to 
establish whether such potential should be investigated in more depth as Mongolia 
seeks to diversify its export base. 
 
12.  Output 2: Awareness of the potential scope and benefits of NAPSI using Mongolian 
renewable  power  increased.  In  designing  and  executing  the  analytical  approach  for  the 
components of output 1, ADB staff and consultants will engage with stakeholders from all relevant 
NAPSI countries (Japan, PRC, the ROK, and the Russian Federation) through North-East Asia 
Regional Power Interconnection and Cooperation Forum meetings and TA workshops, with 
targeted participation of women of 25% or more.12 Ensuring that stakeholders agree on the 
approach and are well informed about the outcome of the analyses will contribute to a shared 
understanding of the value of renewable contributions from Mongolia in the development of 
NAPSI, which supports the region’s GHG mitigation and air quality goals. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $895,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Clean Energy Fund13 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility and 
(ii) $350,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund, both to be administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff, 
secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize 
workshops; and coordinate with other development partners and multilateral agencies on related 
initiatives in close cooperation with the Ministry of Energy, the TA’s executing agency. 
 
 
12 Target reflects low female participation in power trading dialogue.  
13 Financing partners: the governments of Australia, Norway, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom.

5

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.14 
 
18.  Cofinancier requirements. The TA team will submit progress status report semiannually 
and completion report within a year after project completion to the Partner Funds Division of ADB’s 
Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change  Department,  and  additional  updates  (as 
necessary) on project implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility, and (ii) ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding the 
equivalent of $350,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund to Mongolia for the Promotion of the Northeast Asia Power System 
Interconnection, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
14 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
